data.title: Work around incorrect data on `compositionupdate` events in Chrome 56
data.body:
Fixes #14911

The `compositionupdate` event is associated with a `data` property that is supposed to contain the full in-progress state of the composed string. Due to a [bug in Chrome](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=677050) that has been resolved as of Electron 1.7, that field only contains the most recently typed character in Electron 1.6.

This PR attempts to work around this on Chrome 56 by reading the contents of the hidden input field directly rather than relying on the incorrect `data` property. Since `compositionupdate` events seem to be fired prior to the contents of the input field changing, I perform the read on `process.nextTick` after the browser has a chance to update the field.

One extra wrinkle is I now *clear* the input field on `compositionstart` events so that previous input doesn't pollute the previewed composition. The only keystrokes that could potentially pollute the preview are spaces, since we use `preventDefault` in our `textInput` event handler to prevent every other character from actually being inserted. If we `preventDefault` on space however, it causes the browser's default behavior of scrolling on space, so we have to let that one through. It's okay though, because we're clearing it out when the composition starts.

/cc @ungb @Ben3eeE

data.title: Mouse clicking doesn't work after trying to close a tab using wheel click
data.body:
Clicking mouse wheel on a not saved file blocks subsequent mouse clicks. You are shown a pop-up with warning that file was changed, but you can't click on the  buttons - Save, Cancel or Don't save. You also can not click on workspace, launcher buttons, etc. Only a keyboard is available, so you can close modal window via Esc press or Alt + F4.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Change any file - new or existing, but don't save it
2. Click on the file tab using a mouse wheel to close it
3. Modal window with warning about unsaved files appears
4. Try to click any button or another program window

**Expected behavior:** Mouse clicking should work - you can close the modal window or switch to another program

**Actual behavior:** Mouse clicking doesn't work

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
Ubuntu 16.04 LTS 64-bit

**Additional information
If you close a tab by clicking on tab's cross, all is ok. The same is true for Ctrl + w combination.

data.title: Blurry Text when scrolling
data.body:
Since yesterday (automatic updates) the text gets blurry when I scroll in certain positions.

Example:
![blurry text atom](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14870322/29210219-5dc24c7e-7e8a-11e7-9e93-f268517ab049.png)

Adding a few new lines at the bottom of the page (temporarily and partially) solves the issue.

data.title: Ignore `package-lock.json`
data.body:
When building Atom with newer version of npm,
it would generate `package-lock.json` at

  - `apm/package-lock.json`
  - `script/package-lock.json`

Maybe we can add `package-lock.json` to [`.gitignore`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/.gitignore) to avoid accidentally add it to git index.

data.title: Projects no longer in one window using separate tabs.
data.body:
Prior to Atom 1.18, projects used to open in the same window, using tabs (not file tabs, but window tabs). While I did skip 1.18 version and went directly to 1.19, this feature also seems to have been removed. Was this an explicit removal or an unintended bug?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a project. 
2. Using recent project (or the other package), try to open a another project.

**Expected behavior:**

Expected project to open in the same window, using window tabs.

**Actual behavior:**

Project opens in new window completely.

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

Affects 1.18+

data.title: Cursor is visible on multiple input fields
data.body:
Since updating to the new Atom 1.20 the cursor is visible on multiple input fields, I tried removing the compiled-cache to no avail. This seems to be a bug or compatibility issue.

data.title: `git rebase` not working properly with atom editor
data.body:
I have been using atom as my preferred editor with git for a long time by way of
`git config --global core.editor "atom --wait"`

I commonly do `git rebase -i <hash>`.  As of the 1.19.0 release after putting the rebase command in the console, a list of seemingly unrelated commits is presented to me.  If I delete all the lines/commits presented to me in order to cancel the operation (git responds 'nothing to do'), and repeat the rebase command, the proper commits are listed the *second* time and all is well.

This is on Debian Linxux v9 and git version 2.11.0.

data.title: Shim rowsPerPage property on Editor instances
data.body:
Several packages were relying on a raw property rather than the getter method. This isn't really officially supported, but may as well keep them working.

Fixes https://github.com/callum-ramage/ctrl-dir-scroll/issues/28

data.title: Atom 1.19.0 breaks scrolling in plugin.
data.body:
With Atom 1.19.0, I can no longer use `Ctrl+Up` and `Ctrl+Down` to scroll using the https://github.com/callum-ramage/ctrl-dir-scroll/ plugin.

Before someone says "go file an issue on the `ctrl-dir-scroll` project" (note I already have: https://github.com/callum-ramage/ctrl-dir-scroll/issues/28), keep in mind that this plugin has not been modified since February of this year (almost eight months ago).

In fact Atom 1.19.0 has significant changes that break several plugins. For example https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15225 completely breaks https://github.com/Glavin001/atom-beautify , corrupting content and losing data. As far as I can tell, this was caused by changed in Atom, not by something new in the plugin; see https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15225 .

I suspect this is yet another instance of significant Atom changes in 1.19.0 breaking things. If I don't report it here, then no one may ever look into it. Thanks for any info you can find.

data.title: Cursor Position Indicator renders inside of characters
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After upgrade from 1.18 to 1.19, Cursor position is broken and causes the cursor to show up INSIDE of the text, rather than the end of each character. See screenshot:
![cursor-indicator](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20247733/29179698-e45526ba-7dba-11e7-9a8c-1f095aa48e65.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Normal operation

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Cursor indicator between characters properly

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Cursor position renders inside of characters

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

1.19.0
You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
Windows 10 x64 (latest)
1080p with no dpi scaling.
Changing text size in atom.io has no effect

data.title: Create, update and destroy highlights manually
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15185.

Etch's reconciliation routine causes elements to be sometimes re-ordered. In order to move an element, however, Etch needs to first detach it from the DOM and then re-append it at the right location.

This behavior is unacceptable for highlight decorations because it could re-start CSS animations on a certain highlight decoration when a completely different one is added or removed.

Even though we are still interested in restructuring etch's reconciliation logic to prevent unwanted re-orderings, with this commit we are switching to a custom routine to create/update/remove highlight decorations that prevents unnecessary moves and, as a result, fixes the undesired behavior described above.

/cc: @nathansobo @t9md

data.title: Horizontal scrolling is always favored over vertical scrolling
data.body:
Hey,

I can't see anything about it in the release notes but it's possible I've missed something. I've just updated to Atom 1.19.0 (OS X 10.12.6, MacBook Pro) and for some reason the horizontal scroll seems to have started catching when it shouldn't. It's hard to explain but, if you're using two fingers on the trackpad to vertically scroll up and down a file then, since the update, as you scroll it seems to catch horizontally much more often and start scrolling that way instead.

Has any of the sensitivity been changed? Am I missing something?

---

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On long files where horizontal scrolling is possible the horizontal scrolling sensitivity is now higher and kicks in when scrolling vertically.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Make sure you're using a Mac.
2. Get a long file with lines that exceed the width of the screen.
3. Use two fingers on the trackpad to scroll vertically down the screen, if your fingers are at anything other than perfectly aligned then the horizontal scroll kicks in much sooner than it did before.

**Expected behavior:**

To scroll vertically, smoothly.

**Actual behavior:**

As you scroll vertically, it start scrolling horizontally

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: Pressing "Cancel" on an unsaved buffer dialog will not cancel a restart
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

**Pressing "Cancel" on the unsaved buffer dialog will not cancel a restart**

Atom requests a restart in some situations, such as when a plugin has been updated. If one has an unsaved buffer open in a project-less window, after pressing "restart", the normal unsaved file dialog is presented with, on macOS at least, "Save", "Don't Save", and "Cancel" buttons. In this scenario, "Save" and "Don't Save" work as expected, but pressing "Cancel" will immediately re-present the same dialog. This can be especially problematic when the unsaved buffer is in another tab in the same window as one cannot switch tabs to inspect the file and determine if it should be saved or not.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new project-less window and buffer
2. Type in some content
3. Trigger a restart by either updating plugins or opening a developer console and entering `atom.restartApplication()`
4. Press "Cancel"

**Expected behavior:**
The restart operation should be canceled, returning me to the state I was in before I pressed "restart".

**Actual behavior:**
I am immediately presented with the same unsaved buffer dialog

**Reproduces how often:**
Every time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
macOS: 10.12.6

data.title: incompatible with Microsoft Pinyin

And this is what I have typed:

data.title: Uncaught (in promise) Error: EOVERFLOW, Unknown error
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
I want to be clear I have not been able to reproduce after I solved the problem. Been trying for 2 days now. But was such a strange problem and behavior I felt i should report it. 

I closed atom 2 nights ago and when I reopened it the following morning. No tabs were showing. It was just the menu. Not git browser, project tree, ect. just about everything in the menus didn't respond.  The program wasn't locked up as I could open and close the menus, but it wouldn't open the settings, packages, or even reopen my project. This is what it looked like: https://prnt.sc/g6s8yo

So I started working through the debug steps. I check to ensure i was on the latest version (1.19). 
I then closed it out and reopened it in safe mode. The problem was still there. I then closed it and cleared the save state and reopened it normal mode and cleared the saved state and reopened in safe mode. The problem was still there. I then closed it and moved the <user>\.atom folder. repeating again opening in normal and safe mode. Problem continued. I checked for links and there were none. I had to skip the "Check Atom and Package Settings" because I was unable to open the settings or packages sections inside of atom. 

I restored my original <user>\.atom folder again to check for font rendering issues. I noticed a error count in the developer window. So when I switch to the console. I saw:
Uncaught (in promise) Error: EOVERFLOW, Unknown error
C:\wamp64\www\influxproject\html\application\helpers\myform_helper.php

Curious i closed Atom and reset to factory again and cleared saved state. When I open it back up and reopened the developer console. again I saw the same error. It made no since that point as to how and why it knew about that file after clearing the save state and restoring to factory default. I opened the file up in Notepad++ and turned on all symbols. I skimmed through the file looking for anything that seemed like it might not belong. I couldn't find anything. 

So I closed atom and moved the file to someplace else. When i reopened atom everything was back to normal. Thinking it might just be the file it's self still. I closed atom moved the file back to where it was and reopened atom. Yet when it opened Atom was acting normally like there wasn't even a problem. 



### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
2. [Second Step]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

### Versions
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS: Windows 10 Pro x64

### Additional Information
Attached is the crash log which apears to contain no real info of note, but included just in case. 
[operation_log.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1215029/operation_log.txt)

---

See https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15236#issuecomment-322099135
